Introduction

Refeeding syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by significant shifts in fluid and electrolyte levels following the reintroduction of nutrition in chronically malnourished individuals (eg, anorexia nervosa).  It is most notably associated with severe hypophosphatemia, which can precipitate complications including cardiac arrhythmias, congestive heart failure, seizures, muscle weakness, and respiratory failure.

Pathogenesis



During prolonged starvation, the body conserves energy by decreasing insulin levels and increasing glucagon levels, shifting metabolism toward lipolysis (fat breakdown) and proteolysis (muscle breakdown).  This adaptation gradually depletes intracellular stores of essential vitamins (eg, thiamine) and electrolytes (eg, phosphate, potassium, magnesium), even though serum levels may remain normal.



Upon refeeding, particularly with carbohydrate-rich nutrition, insulin secretion surges, driving glucose, phosphate, potassium, and magnesium into cells.  This leads to a precipitous decrease in the circulating levels of these essential electrolytes.  Insulin also increases phosphate utilization during glycolysis (eg, formation of ATP, 2,3-diphosphoglycerate), further exacerbating phosphate depletion (

Pathogenesis of refeeding syndrome
).



Phosphate is critical for cellular energy production (eg, ATP synthesis) and red blood cell function (eg, 2,3-diphosphoglycerate facilitates oxygen delivery to tissues):



  • Hypophosphatemia:  Hallmark feature of refeeding syndrome that severely impairs glycolysis, limits ATP production, and reduces oxygen release from hemoglobin, leading to cellular hypoxia and multiorgan dysfunction.  Clinical consequences include decreased myocardial contractility, cardiac arrhythmias, respiratory muscle weakness/respiratory failure, hemolysis, rhabdomyolysis, and seizures.


Additional biochemical abnormalities observed in refeeding syndrome include:



  • Hypokalemia:  Disrupts cellular membrane potential and conduction, causing arrhythmias (eg, torsades de pointes) and muscle weakness/paralysis.
  • Hypomagnesemia:  Increases potassium wasting and exacerbates hypokalemia; also contributes to neuromuscular dysfunction.
  • Sodium and water retention:  Insulin stimulates renal sodium (and water) reabsorption in the distal nephron, leading to fluid overload (eg, pulmonary edema) and heart strain.
  • Thiamine deficiency:  Thiamine is a vital cofactor in carbohydrate metabolism.  Reintroduction of glucose in malnourished patients with depleted thiamine stores can precipitate Wernicke encephalopathy (ie, confusion, oculomotor dysfunction, ataxia).

Risk factors



Patients at highest risk include those with poor nutrition or starvation who are rapidly fed.  Risk factors include:



  • Eating disorders (eg, anorexia nervosa).
  • Chronic alcohol use disorder.
  • Postbariatric surgery.
  • Malabsorptive conditions (eg, inflammatory bowel disease).
  • Prolonged malnutrition (eg, cancer, chronic illness).
  • Very low BMI (<16 kg/mÂ²).

Clinical presentation



Symptoms typically begin within 2-5 days of initiating feeding.  The clinical manifestations are highly variable and may include:



  • Neurologic:  Weakness, tremors, paresthesias, seizures, delirium, Wernicke encephalopathy.
  • Cardiac:  Arrhythmias, pulmonary/peripheral edema, congestive heart failure, hypotension, shock, cardiac arrest.
  • Respiratory:  Dyspnea and hypoventilation due to diaphragmatic muscle weakness, respiratory failure.
  • Gastrointestinal:  Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, ileus.
  • Musculoskeletal:  Myalgias, rhabdomyolysis.
  • Hematologic:  Hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia.
  • Renal:  Acute tubular necrosis, renal failure, metabolic acidosis.
  • General:  Fatigue, sudden death.

Differential diagnosis



  • Hyperparathyroidism:  Hypophosphatemia, muscle weakness, neurologic symptoms, and occasionally rhabdomyolysis may occur.  However, these features occur independently of nutritional depletion or refeeding.
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA):  Insulin therapy for DKA management induces intracellular shifts of potassium, phosphate, and magnesium similar to those seen in refeeding syndrome.  However, these shifts occur in the context of exogenous insulin therapy, not nutritional repletion.
  • Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS):  This results from the rapid breakdown of malignant cells, typically after chemotherapy.  TLS can result in profound electrolyte abnormalities, including hyperkalemia (not hypokalemia), hyperphosphatemia (not hypophosphatemia), hypocalcemia, and acute kidney injury.
  • Chronic alcohol use:  Hypophosphatemia, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and thiamine deficiency are associated conditions.  Although biochemically similar to refeeding syndrome, electrolyte abnormalities are typically pre-existing rather than triggered by nutritional support.

Diagnosis



Refeeding syndrome is primarily a clinical diagnosis supported by a history of recent refeeding after a period of malnutrition/starvation and laboratory findings that include hypophosphatemia (most characteristic), hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia.  Fluid overload or organ dysfunction temporally related to refeeding further supports the diagnosis.

Laboratory evaluation



Laboratory testing is used to identify and manage refeeding syndrome:



  • Serum electrolytes:  Frequent monitoring (eg, every 8, 12, or 24 hours) of phosphate, potassium, and magnesium to replace low levels.
  • Renal function tests:  Abnormal kidney function may result from refeeding syndrome and further exacerbate electrolyte and fluid imbalances.
  • Creatine phosphokinase (CPK):  Elevated CPK indicates rhabdomyolysis.
  • Liver function tests:  Biomarkers may be elevated during the early stages of refeeding due to fat deposition (steatosis) from the increased caloric intake, although levels usually normalize over time without significant clinical implications.
  • Complete blood count:  This should be performed to evaluate for hemolysis.
  • Arterial blood gas (ABG):  This should be performed in cases of respiratory compromise or failure.

Imaging studies



Imaging is not diagnostic but may be helpful in assessing complications.  Studies may include a chest x-ray (for pulmonary edema or cardiomegaly due to fluid overload), ECG (for arrhythmias due to electrolyte abnormalities), and echocardiogram (for decreased contractility due to electrolyte abnormalities).

Management and prevention



The mainstay of management involves identification of at-risk patients to assess nutritional status and baseline electrolytes before initiating feeding.



  • Gradual reintroduction of nutrition:  Start at 10-20 kcal/kg/day in high-risk individuals and advance caloric intake slowly over 4-7 days.
  • Electrolyte monitoring and replacement:  Perform preemptive and ongoing replacement of phosphate, potassium, and magnesium.
  • Thiamine supplementation:  Administer thiamine (100-300 mg daily) before and during the initial refeeding phase to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.
  • Fluid management:  Avoid fluid overload (eg, restrict sodium and fluid intake) and monitor for signs of heart failure.

Prognosis



With early recognition and appropriate intervention, the prognosis is favorable.  However, if left untreated, refeeding syndrome can be fatal.  Mortality rates are higher in elderly and critically ill patients, largely due to arrhythmias or organ failure.

Summary



Refeeding syndrome is a serious and potentially life-threatening condition seen in malnourished individuals upon reintroduction of nutrition.  Its hallmark feature is hypophosphatemia, but other electrolyte and fluid abnormalities can lead to multiorgan dysfunction.  Prevention is through early identification of at-risk individuals, nutritional supplementation, and frequent laboratory monitoring.  Aggressive electrolyte replacement reduces morbidity and mortality.
